description: Siting of 2nos mobile homes in rear garden for ancillary residential use associated with the dwellinghouse.
decision_conditions: The applicant has failed to demonstrate on the balance of probability  that on 10 January 2025 the use / operations described in the First Schedule hereto in respect of the land specified in the First Schedule hereto was lawful within the meaning of section 191(2) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) for the following reason(s):The mobile homes were not in situ at the time that the application was submitted on 10.01.2025. Accordingly, a Certificate of Existing Use, Operation or Activity could not be issued under Section 191 of The Town and Country Planning Act (1990)

Notwithstanding the first reason for refusal, The applicant has failed to demonstrate on the balance of probability  that on 10 January 2025 the use / operations described in the First Schedule hereto in respect of the land specified in the First Schedule hereto was lawful within the meaning of section 192(2) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) for the following reason(s):As a matter of fact and degree it is considered that, on the balance of probability, the proposed mobile homes are buildings which require planning permission and they do not benefit from permission via a Development Order i.e. does not amount to permitted development.It has not been demonstrated that, on the balance of probability, the proposed mobile homes would be sited within the residential curtilage of the dwellinghouse and would be ancillary to the dwellinghouse. As such, the proposal would amount to a material change of use of the land amounting to development requiring planning permission and the use does not benefit from permission via a Development Order i.e. does not amount to permitted development.Enabling works which potentially comprise engineering, waste disposal and/or other building operations appear to have been carried out. Accordingly, it has not been demonstrated that the totality of the works are lawful. As such, the proposal would comprise engineering works amounting to development requiring planning permission and the works do not benefit from permission via a Development Order i.e. does not amount to permitted development.
